Here i have a detailed answer for this decision:
If you want the back arrow you just have to set the following in your application
java
getSupportActionBar().setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true);
This will work for an ActionBar or Toolbar. 
So now there is one thing. This won't show the back arrow if we use an ActionBarDrawerToggle because this overwrites this behavior. So we have to disable this for our drawer by setting the following
java
.withActionBarDrawerToggle(false)
For the functionality to go back you need the default implementation like this:
``` java
@Override
    public boolean onOptionsItemSelected(MenuItem item) {
        switch (item.getItemId()) {
            case android.R.id.home:
                onBackPressed();
                return true;
        default:
            return super.onOptionsItemSelected(item);
    }
}

```
Deciding if i want the ActionBarDrawerToggle or the BackArrow? 
Yeah it is a really simple decision because the Material Design Guidelines (or some other google android guidelines :D) state that a Drawer is just for the Main (the first) activity within your application. 
So one more thing. The Drawer itself overlaps the toolbar so it will also overlap the ActionBarDrawerToggle so it won't show the arrow. So why do we have the ActionBarDrawerToggle in this case. Because it's easier for me to implement the callbacks for the Hamburger click. And for the really rare usecase that someone does not have a fullscreen (full-height) drawer which will show the ActionBarDrawerToggle (and if this dev also enables the animation)

So as a detailed description what it does, or how i came to this solution. I tried a lot of different things, disabling the fullscreen or changing ui flags if the drawer is not shown or many additional things, but nothing changed. just a few things made the ui look ugly. so i checked some google apps as you did, and as i wrote above i checked the google keep app. 
Everytime the keyboard showed up it changed the height of the containing view (adding enough padding/margin at the bottom) so i checked how i can do the same for our app. 
I wrote a listener which reacts on the layout height change and calculates if it could be a keyboard. at the moment it reacts starting with 100dp (SwiftKey with the smallest setting takes 240dp) i then use the difference to the main height change and add the padding to the containing view. not to the root of the application but to the container for the fragments. So here's the code which does the magic:
Whole source can be found here: https://github.com/mikepenz/MaterialDrawer/blob/aa9136fb4f5b3a80460fe5f47213985026d20c88/library/src/main/java/com/mikepenz/materialdrawer/util/KeyboardUtil.java
``` java
private View decorView;
    private View contentView;
public KeyboardUtil(Activity act, View contentView) {
    this.decorView = act.getWindow().getDecorView();
    this.contentView = contentView;

    //only required on newer android versions. it was working on API level 19
    if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 19) {
        decorView.getViewTreeObserver().addOnGlobalLayoutListener(onGlobalLayoutListener);
    }
}

public void enable() {
    if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 19) {
        decorView.getViewTreeObserver().addOnGlobalLayoutListener(onGlobalLayoutListener);
    }
}

public void disable() {
    if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 19) {
        decorView.getViewTreeObserver().removeOnGlobalLayoutListener(onGlobalLayoutListener);
    }
}


//a small helper to allow showing the editText focus
ViewTreeObserver.OnGlobalLayoutListener onGlobalLayoutListener = new ViewTreeObserver.OnGlobalLayoutListener() {
    @Override
    public void onGlobalLayout() {
        Rect r = new Rect();
        //r will be populated with the coordinates of your view that area still visible.
        decorView.getWindowVisibleDisplayFrame(r);

        //get screen height and calculate the difference with the useable area from the r
        int height = decorView.getContext().getResources().getDisplayMetrics().heightPixels;
        int diff = height - r.bottom;

        //if it could be a keyboard add the padding to the view
        if (diff != 0) {
            // if the use-able screen height differs from the total screen height we assume that it shows a keyboard now
            //check if the padding is 0 (if yes set the padding for the keyboard)
            if (contentView.getPaddingBottom() != diff) {
                //set the padding of the contentView for the keyboard
                contentView.setPadding(0, 0, 0, diff);
            }
        } else {
            //check if the padding is != 0 (if yes reset the padding)
            if (contentView.getPaddingBottom() != 0) {
                //reset the padding of the contentView
                contentView.setPadding(0, 0, 0, 0);
            }
        }
    }
};

```

. @IlyaMyasoedov ok the issue is quite easy to solve and quite easy to understand
Each activity contains of an root layout identified by 'android.R.id.content' this will host the complete layout of your activity. So if you use my library i will take all layouts hosted within this content layout and will inflate it within a drawer. so i do the DrawerLayout by code for you and will manage everything. nothing to handle from your side. Now you come and add the FAB to your activity. 
The fab also contains some similar code as the drawer. if you don't provide the layout which will host this fab it will inflate it within 'android.R.id.content' layout so it will be in a layout which is the parent of the drawer (because we added the drawer earlier). So there are two solutions. you can either inflate the FAB before the drawer. I don't recommend this because it will create another layer within your view hierarchy and this is not needed. 
The cleanest solution is to add the view which will host the fab, and that's the content of the DrawerLayout. You can do this like this:
java
//look at the part with .in(...)
mFloatingAction = FloatingAction.from(this)
                .listenTo(mListView)
                .in(drawerResult.getContent())
                .colorResId(R.color.windowBackground)
                .icon(R.drawable.plus)
                .listener(this)
                .build();
After this the drawer will be above the fab. 
I also saw an additional issue. Your activity_main.xml contains a DrawerLayout which is really unnecessary. It won't be used it will just add another view which hosts the rest of the layout. I recommend to remove it, because the MaterialDrawer handles this for you ;) Keep it simple :D

            }
        @Override
        public void cancel(ImageView imageView) {
            Picasso.with(imageView.getContext()).cancelRequest(imageView);
        }

        @Override

        }

You mentioned you have to search for the position all the time. If you use the identifier which is highly recommend you can directly use updateItem and set the IDrawerItem which will do the following:
First it will get the position for this item, then it will make sure there is an item at this position, and if yes it will set the item to the adapter, which will then trigger a notifyItemChanged so no real overhead here. 
If you want to get to a bit lower level you can also just set the DrawerItem directly to the Adapter 
result.getAdapter().setDrawerItem(position, drawerItem);
this will eliminate the search for the position, the check if this item exists.

package com.mikepenz.materialdrawer.util;
import android.app.Activity;
import android.graphics.Rect;
import android.os.Build;
import android.view.View;
import android.view.ViewTreeObserver;
import android.view.inputmethod.InputMethodManager;
/*
 * Created by mikepenz on 14.03.15.
 * This class implements a hack to change the layout padding on bottom if the keyboard is shown
 * to allow long lists with editTextViews
 * Basic idea for this solution found here: http://stackoverflow.com/a/9108219/325479
 /
public class KeyboardUtil {
    private View decorView;
    private View contentView;
public KeyboardUtil(Activity act, View contentView) {
    this.decorView = act.getWindow().getDecorView();
    this.contentView = contentView;

    //only required on newer android versions. it was working on API level 19
    if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 19) {
        decorView.getViewTreeObserver().addOnGlobalLayoutListener(onGlobalLayoutListener);
    }
}

public void enable() {
    if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 19) {
        decorView.getViewTreeObserver().addOnGlobalLayoutListener(onGlobalLayoutListener);
    }
}

public void disable() {
    if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 19) {
        decorView.getViewTreeObserver().removeOnGlobalLayoutListener(onGlobalLayoutListener);
    }
}


//a small helper to allow showing the editText focus
ViewTreeObserver.OnGlobalLayoutListener onGlobalLayoutListener = new ViewTreeObserver.OnGlobalLayoutListener() {
    @Override
    public void onGlobalLayout() {
        Rect r = new Rect();
        //r will be populated with the coordinates of your view that area still visible.
        decorView.getWindowVisibleDisplayFrame(r);

        int height = decorView.getContext().getResources().getDisplayMetrics().heightPixels;
        int bottom = r.bottom;

        //if it could be a keyboard add the padding to the view
        if (bottom - height != 0) {
            // if the use-able screen height differs from the total screen height we assume that it shows a keyboard now
            //check if the padding is 0 (if yes set the padding for the keyboard)
            if (contentView.getPaddingBottom() == 0) {
                //set the padding of the contentView for the keyboard
                contentView.setPadding(0, 0, 0, height - bottom);
            }
        } else {
            //check if the padding is != 0 (if yes reset the padding)
            if (contentView.getPaddingBottom() != 0) {
                //reset the padding of the contentView
                contentView.setPadding(0, 0, 0, 0);
            }
        }
    }
};


/**
 * Helper to hide the keyboard
 *
 * @param act
 */
public static void hideKeyboard(Activity act) {
    if (act != null && act.getCurrentFocus() != null) {
        InputMethodManager inputMethodManager = (InputMethodManager) act.getSystemService(Activity.INPUT_METHOD_SERVICE);
        inputMethodManager.hideSoftInputFromWindow(act.getCurrentFocus().getWindowToken(), 0);
    }
}

}

            mTitle.setText("FragmentOne");

. @rsd-raul i'm not quite sure what you mean that you miss the possibility to add an OnDrawerListener to the drawer after creation. 
The code you padded mixes up the DrawerListener and the OnDrawerItemClickListener. 
You can provide a different OnDrawerItemClickListener for each of the two drawers. The left (main) one, and the right (appended) one. 
You are right that there is only one OnDrawerListener which you set via .withOnDrawerListener(new Drawer.OnDrawerListener() { on the left (main) drawer via it's builder. 
But this will provide a View with the event, which you can check if it is the left or right drawer. 
``` java
.withOnDrawerListener(new Drawer.OnDrawerListener() {
                    @Override
                    public void onDrawerOpened(View drawerView) {
                        if (drawerView == result.getSlider()) {
                            Log.e("sample", "left opened");
                        } else if (drawerView == resultAppended.getSlider()) {
                            Log.e("sample", "right opened");
                        }
                    }
                @Override
                public void onDrawerClosed(View drawerView) {
                    if (drawerView == result.getSlider()) {
                        Log.e("sample", "left closed");
                    } else if (drawerView == resultAppended.getSlider()) {
                        Log.e("sample", "right closed");
                    }
                }

                @Override
                public void onDrawerSlide(View drawerView, float slideOffset) {

                }
            })

```
This should do the thing you want to achieve.

To make it more transparent for devs, the FastAdapter only works with the global position. In an earlier version i worked with the relative position (depending on the adapter used) but this was to confusing. So i switched to global positions only. So that means if ther eis a header, the first position of your items is 1 if no header is there the first position is 0.
So you may ask now why does it fail with position 0 if there is a header. To get the global position i substract the number of items which are in the prior adapter. So HeaderAdapter with 1 item, ItemAdapter with X items. To get the global position here, i substract position provided by 1 (where 1 is the cound of items inside the HeaderAdapter)

. @bignadad 2 things. 
First you define the same drawable for the selected, and for the general state. 
Second you set the background as Drawable for the itemView not the stateListDrawable
Here's a simplified variant:
``` java
public class CustomPrimaryDrawerItemPro extends PrimaryDrawerItem {
    @Override
    public void bindView(ViewHolder holder) {
        super.bindView(holder);
    StateListDrawable stateListDrawable = new StateListDrawable();
    //define the color we want to use for the selected state (this is the default one defined via theme and is defined via the material design guidelines)
    stateListDrawable.addState(new int[]{android.R.attr.state_selected}, new ColorDrawable(getSelectedColor(holder.itemView.getContext())));
    //define the color which is used for the general state
    stateListDrawable.addState(new int[]{}, new ColorDrawable(Color.RED));
    //set the color for the view
    holder.itemView.setBackgroundDrawable(stateListDrawable);
}

}
``

. @Strayer thanks for your detailed issue. 
The behavior of this has changed starting with v5.0.0. The root cause for this is the switch from built in adapter to the FastAdapter. So you may ask why I have decided to go with this. 
The main point is that I wanted consistency between the position you get from the listeners and the positions you have to pass if you want to modify something. 
So why will the first item be at position 1 if there is a header, and 0 if there is none? Yeah that comes because the Header is also just an item within the RecyclerView 
The internal structure looks like this. 
HeaderAdapter
ItemAdapter
FooterAdapter
StickyFooterArea (completely out of scope of the RV)
So the count of items of the header will count up the positions in the normal ItemAdapter and also in the FooterAdapter 
As you already correctly foudn the getGlobalPosition() method. It basically checks the position of the adapter you are calling it on (Theoretically there could be more as 3 (as it is the case for the drawer)) and will then add the number of items before the current adapter, so you can work with relative positions. 
I hope this clears up your confusion a bit :)

. @kakai248 as of v5.0.0 and upwards the MaterialDrawer depends on the fitsSystemWindows flag to manage the paddings and shadow behind the StatusBar everything is now handled by the system. 
If this is possible with a normal DrawerLayout and the flags it is also possible with the MaterialDrawer. 
More or less this was a good side effect of the previous implementation as paddings were managed manually (it required the fullscreen flag which had other side effects).
I think the only way how you could get this working is to use 2 DrawerLayouts where one is fitsSystemWindows=true and the other one fitsSystemWindows=false (which will prevent any CollapsingToolbar behaviors etc. Content won't be possible to go behind the StatusBar)
I highly recommend that you don't do this because this will add another view layer, and might cause lower performance.

I see a few problems with your issue / solution. 
The first issue is. You do not use the default behavior when creating the Drawer you use the .buildView() method which won't inflate and add the DrawerLayout for you. So the Drawer does not know about the DrawerLayout and it won't handle it for you. 
If you want a DrawerLayout in the root of your activity I suggest to use the .build() method which will then result in everything being handled for you automatically. You will also be able to call Drawer.getDrawerLayout() then to retrieve the managed DrawerLayout 
as of openDrawer() and closeDrawer() those methods are meant to open and close it. Not to lock it. 
After that you will be able to LOCK /  UNLOCK the Slider of the Drawer using the platform methods. You may need to use the GravityCompat.START to get the correct view locked. 
You may want to check the different lock modes here:
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v4/widget/DrawerLayout.html#LOCK_MODE_LOCKED_CLOSED

. @Pteranodon sorry this can't be merged as it has some big issues related to the way RecyclerViews handle their elements. 
The view of an element inside the RecyclerView is always reused. So if you scroll it will reuse the view and use it for the next element in the list. So what will happen:
Our list with some elements
ElemA_1 (view 1) (in your case this element a gets now view 1 set) 
ElemA_2 (view 2) (in your case this element a gets now view 2 set) 
ElemB_1 (view 3)
ElemC_1 (view 4)
ElemA_3 (view 5) (in your case this element a gets now view 5 set) 
----- outside the current window
ElemA_4 (no view applied at all at the moment)
ElemA_5 (no view applied at all at the moment)
Fine in the above scenario it will work, every element has it's own view applied, if you run your code above everything works as expected. But now the user scrolls down:
ElemA_1 (in your case this element has still view 1 set) 
ElemA_2 (in your case this element has still view 2 set) 
----- outside the current window
ElemB_1 (view 3)
ElemC_1 (view 4)
ElemA_3 (view 5) (in your case this element a gets now view 5 set) 
ElemA_4 (view 1) (in your case this element gets now also view 1 applied)
ElemA_5 (view 2) (in your case this element gets now also view 2 applied)
So when you run your code again. Suddenly ElemA_1 and ElemA_4 will share the same view, and the same for 2 and 5. 
So as a result of this, you can not get the view from an item. You can just get the views from items if you directly access the RecyclerView and get the view of a specific position inside the view.

You have to keep in mind that the MaterialDrawer is "just" a wrapper around the DrawerLayout and provides you some easy to use APIs which allow you to achieve a Drawer following the material design guidelines.

You can easily to this by calling Drawer.getSlider() as the DrawerLayout manages the gravity just by this (the sliders) gravity. Just update the gravity for the Slider view and you should be good to go.

As such it will not be able to find the views and they stay null.

``` Java
result.getActionBarDrawerToggle().setDrawerIndicatorEnabled(false);
getSupportActionBar().setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true);
getSupportActionBar().setDisplayShowHomeEnabled(true);
```
IMPORTANT: the order of the previous lines matters. If you disable the drawer after setting the displayhome, it doesn't show
To recover the hambuger the oposite must be done:
Java
getSupportActionBar().setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(false);
getSupportActionBar().setDisplayShowHomeEnabled(false);
result.getActionBarDrawerToggle().setDrawerIndicatorEnabled(true);

. This seems to be an issue with the Android support library v4. espresso-contrib:2.0 depends on support-v4 version 21.0.3. MaterialDrawer 2.0.7 (the last released version @kaushald reported as working with Espresso) also depends on support-v4 21.0.3, while subsequent releases (2.5.0+) were upgraded to version 22.0.0 (targeting SDK 22). Having both versions in the dependency tree seems to cause the problem. Reverting the target SDK and support-v4 version in the MaterialDrawer library resolves the issue, but the better solution is probably to exclude the support-v4 module from the espresso-contrib:2.0 dependency in the app as such:
androidTestCompile('com.android.support.test.espresso:espresso-contrib:2.0') {
    exclude module: 'support-annotations'
    exclude module: 'support-v4'
}

Solutions
1. Remove Material Design Library (third-party library, NOT official).
2. Import Material Design Library (third-party library) without Gradle and rename 'rippleColor' from attributes.xml.
3. Wait for the developer of Material Design Library (third-party library).

The issue is in this line.
By default, the getDescriptionTextColor() returns null, so .applyToOr() will apply the currently selected color from the second state list.
but getSelectedColor(ctx) returns the background color, while getSelectedTextColor(ctx) returns the selected text color.
This means if no description text color is defined (using withDescriptionTextColor()), then it will set the text color of the description to the background color.

On Sat, Jun 11, 2016 at 7:03 PM, Mike Penz notifications@github.com wrote:

@Pteranodon https://github.com/Pteranodon sorry this can't be merged as
it has some big issues related to the way RecyclerViews handle their
elements.
The view of an element inside the RecyclerView is always reused. So if
you scroll it will reuse the view and use it for the next element in the
list. So what will happen:
Our list with some elements
ElemA_1 (view 1) (in your case this element a gets now view 1 set)
ElemA_2 (view 2) (in your case this element a gets now view 2 set)
ElemB_1 (view 3)
ElemC_1 (view 4)
ElemA_3 (view 5) (in your case this element a gets now view 5 set)
----- outside the current window
ElemA_4
ElemA_5
Fine in the above scenario it will work, every element has it's own view
applied, if you run your code above everything works as expected. But now
the user scrolls down:
ElemA_1 (in your case this element has still view 1 set)
ElemA_2 (in your case this element has still view 2 set)
----- outside the current window
ElemB_1 (view 3)
ElemC_1 (view 4)
ElemA_3 (view 5) (in your case this element a gets now view 5 set)
ElemA_4 (view 1) (in your case this element gets now also view 1 applied)
ElemA_5 (view 2) (in your case this element gets now also view 2 applied)
So when you run your code again. Suddenly ElemA_1 and ElemA_4 will share
the same view, and the same for 2 and 5.
So as a result of this, you can not get the view from an item. You can
just get the views from items if you directly access the RecyclerView and
get the view of a specific position inside the view.
